abstract: Sweeping, sulphur burning and wig brushing were among the preparations taking place as the British Parliament prepared to reconvene.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — They are all getting ready for the meeting of Parliament on Tuesday. The House of Commons is being swept and garnished. Sulphur is being burnt to drive out the influenza microbes. Guy Fawkes is being searched for in the cellars. The officials are brushing up their wigs, gowns, and Court suits. Members of the Government, who have had an easy time of it for some months, will now have to keep close to the grindstone. The approach of the Session is anything but a joyful event to them. They like the social position and the high salaries which accompany office, but they do not like compulsory attendance in the House of Commons for eight or nine hours a day.
snippet: Sweeping, sulphur burning and wig brushing were among the preparations taking place as the British Parliament prepared to reconvene....

headline.main: 1892: Cleaning Up the House of Commons
